fields.headline: Looking back: Christmas
fields.bodyText: 25 December 1830: Drinking too much over the festive season is not a new phenomenon. In 1830, a group of Manchester tradesmen made a pledge to refrain from offering alcohol to customers. 24 December 1912: Thomas Coward writes about mistletoe, holly and the tradition of Christmas decorations in a Country Diary. 26 December 1916: A captain recalls the sadness of Christmas time for British soldiers during the first world war. 24 December 1925: When Christmas Eve arrives, most of us are ready to go through the pretence that it really is Santa Claus and nobody else who turns the nursery into a place of ‘painted trifles and fantastic toys’. 20 December 1955: The Guardian looks back on Christmases past and concludes that 25 December 1913 was best of all; a time of prosperity, when the upper middle classes could even afford presents for their servants and the newspaper housekeeping columns carried recipes for oyster dishes. 5 December 1985: Not everyone sees the festive season as a season of goodwill. Now disgruntled employees can have a whip-round and order a special skinhead bootagram service for their hated managing director. 26 December 2004: Tens of thousands of people in six countries were killed when the most powerful earthquake in 40 years triggered huge tidal waves that hit coastlines across Asia. Ten years on, we remember the Indian Ocean tsunami on that fateful Boxing Day. 17 November 2011: Felicity Cloake tells us how to bake the perfect Christmas cake. 2 December 2014: We pick the five best and worst politicians’ Christmas cards over the years. Ed Miliband plays happy families while the Cleggs are very relaxed, certainly more so than the Blairs. As for Nigel Farage’s card, it may have been inspired by Emily Thornberry’s white van man photograph. 4 December 2014: Christmas is not known as the most exciting time for music releases and having to endure Last Christmas by Wham! or Mistletoe and Wine by Cliff Richard on a loop fills most people with dread. Here are the worst things inflicted upon human ears this Christmas. 9 December 2014: Do They Know It’s Christmas? The third reincarnation of the Bob Geldof charity single, this time to help fight the ebola epidemic, is not without its detractors. Ebola survivor Will Pooley called Band Aid ‘cringeworthy cultural ignorance’, Lily Allen called it smug and said she preferred to donate ‘actual money’ while Sir Bob seemed to criticise Adele for not returning his calls.
